questions.text: You are seeing a 65-year-old man with a history of progressive systolic heart failure and hypotension in the cardiac care unit. Echocardiogram shows a severe reduction in left ventricular function and you clinically make the diagnosis of cardiogenic shock. You wish to start a medication that will increase the inotropic state of his heart. Which intracellular ion will increase as a result of this medication and will be responsible for increasing myocardial contractility?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cardiogenic shock, increasing intracellular calcium is a key mechanism for improving cardiac contractility. Medications like dobutamine and milrinone work by increasing calcium levels within cardiac myocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding blood pressure measurements?

options.label: A
options.text: Systolic pressure increases and diastolic pressure decreases when measured in more distal arteries.

options.label: B
options.text: Systolic leg blood pressures are usually as much as 20 mmHg lower than arm blood pressures.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of “white coat hypertension” (blood pressures measured in office or hospital settings significantly higher than in nonclinical settings) has been shown to be a myth.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a blood pressure cuff that is too small will result in a marked underestimation of the true blood pressure.

questions.correct_answer: A. Systolic pressure increases and diastolic pressure decreases when measured in more distal arteries.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Systolic pressure increases and diastolic pressure decreases when measured in more distal arteries.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood pressure measurements can be influenced by various factors, including the site of measurement and the size of the blood pressure cuff. Systolic pressure tends to increase, and diastolic pressure tends to decrease in more distal arteries. White coat hypertension is a real phenomenon that can affect blood pressure readings. It's important to use the correct cuff size to obtain accurate blood pressure measurements.
  • ➤ Blood pressure measurements can be influenced by various factors, including the site of measurement and the size of the blood pressure cuff.
  • ➤ Systolic pressure tends to increase, and diastolic pressure tends to decrease in more distal arteries.
  • ➤ White coat hypertension is a real phenomenon that can affect blood pressure readings.
  • ➤ It's important to use the correct cuff size to obtain accurate blood pressure measurements.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing substernal chest pain. You suspect myocardial ischemia based on the history. Which of the following is true regarding the electrocardiogram in myocardial ischemia?

options.label: A
options.text: In acute transmural myocardial ischemia, Q waves typically precede ST-segment elevation by 4–6 hours.

options.label: B
options.text: Subendocardial ischemia alone results in ST-segment elevation in the leads corresponding to the anatomic area of ischemia.

options.label: C
options.text: Transmural posterior wall ischemia can result in ST depressions in leads V1–V3.

options.label: D
options.text: Transmural ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF indicate acute transmural ischemia in the anterior wall.

questions.correct_answer: C. Transmural posterior wall ischemia can result in ST depressions in leads V1–V3.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transmural posterior wall ischemia can result in ST depressions in leads V1–V3.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ST-segment elevation is a hallmark of acute transmural myocardial ischemia. Subendocardial ischemia typically results in ST-segment depression. Posterior wall ischemia can manifest as ST-segment depression in the anterior leads (V1-V3). It's important to recognize the ECG changes associated with myocardial ischemia to facilitate prompt diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ ST-segment elevation is a hallmark of acute transmural myocardial ischemia.
  • ➤ Subendocardial ischemia typically results in ST-segment depression.
  • ➤ Posterior wall ischemia can manifest as ST-segment depression in the anterior leads (V1-V3).
  • ➤ It's important to recognize the ECG changes associated with myocardial ischemia to facilitate prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: You are seeing a 53-year-old man complaining of occasional, pressure like chest discomfort. The discomfort seems to worsen when he exerts himself, and he has to stop when climbing stairs to allow it to dissipate. You suspect coronary artery disease, and he is not amenable to any invasive testing such as coronary angiography. Which non-invasive test given here has the highest sensitivity currently for detecting stenosis in major coronary arteries?

options.label: D
options.text: Single-photon emission computed tomography myocardial perfusion imaging

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coronary CT angiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient is not amenable to invasive coronary angiography, CCTA is the non-invasive test with the highest sensitivity for detecting significant coronary artery stenosis.
  • ➤ CCTA can help guide further management decisions, such as the need for revascularization or medical therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common mechanism of cardiac arrhythmia?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reentry is the most frequent mechanism underlying cardiac arrhythmias. Understanding the different mechanisms of arrhythmias is crucial for their diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ Reentry is the most frequent mechanism underlying cardiac arrhythmias.
  • ➤ Understanding the different mechanisms of arrhythmias is crucial for their diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) complicated by nephropathy, hemolytic anemia, and pleuritis. Her disease is well controlled on therapy. She recently discovered that she is pregnant and presents today for prenatal counselling. She specifically is concerned about the effect her disease may have on the infant. You tell her that the most common cardiac complication in children born to mothers with SLE is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atrioventricular block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For mothers with SLE, particularly those with anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies, the most concerning cardiac complication for their infants is the risk of atrioventricular block, making it crucial for healthcare providers to monitor for this condition during prenatal consultations and after birth.

questions.text: You are seeing a retired electrician in your clinic, Mr. Surish. He is a 72-year-old with no past medical history other than well-treated hypertension and presents today with complaints of occasional palpitations. You obtain a 12-lead electrocardiogram, which serendipitously occurs during one of his events. You note a rapid heart rate of 160 beats/min, a narrow QRS complex, and P waves with an abnormal axis occurring before every QRS. You astutely diagnose an atrial tachycardia. Which of the following is true about atrial tachycardia?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial tachycardia can occur in the absence of structural heart disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Atrial tachycardia is the most common etiology of supraventricular tachycardia.

options.label: C
options.text: Atrial tachycardia occurs most often in people younger than age 50.

options.label: D
options.text: Fibrosis in atrial tissue is preventative against atrial tachycardia by preventing reentrant circuits.

questions.correct_answer: A. Atrial tachycardia can occur in the absence of structural heart disease.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atrial tachycardia can occur in the absence of structural heart disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrial tachycardia can occur without structural heart disease, and it is important to assess any individual presenting with palpitations for potential causes that may not involve underlying heart pathology.

questions.text: The clinical consequences of atrial fibrillation are attributable to which of the following pathophysiologic mechanisms?

options.label: B
options.text: Predisposition to thrombus formation in the left atrial appendage with potential embolization

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical consequences of atrial fibrillation are multifactorial and include decreased cardiac output due to loss of atrial contraction, increased risk of thromboembolic events, and symptoms related to rapid ventricular rate.

questions.text: You are caring for Ms. Sarma, a 22-year-old woman with rheumatic mitral stenosis. She presents to your office with worsening dyspnea and you note that she is in atrial fibrillation. She is unclear when exactly her symptoms started. You calculate her CHA2DS2-VASc score as only 1. Which of the following represents the appropriate approach to stroke prevention?

options.label: A
options.text: Arrange for immediate cardioversion to sinus rhythm

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate amiodarone orally and 1 week later arrange electrical cardioversion

questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) Initiate warfarin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis, oral anticoagulation is recommended for stroke prevention, even if their CHA2DS2-VASc score is low. Warfarin is a traditional and effective option, but DOACs may also be considered after careful evaluation. The choice between warfarin and DOACs should be individualized based on the patient's specific risk factors, bleeding risk, and preferences. Shared decision-making is crucial.
  • ➤ In patients with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis, oral anticoagulation is recommended for stroke prevention, even if their CHA2DS2-VASc score is low.
  • ➤ Warfarin is a traditional and effective option, but DOACs may also be considered after careful evaluation.
  • ➤ The choice between warfarin and DOACs should be individualized based on the patient's specific risk factors, bleeding risk, and preferences. Shared decision-making is crucial.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction and congestive heart failure is comfortable at rest. However, when walking to his car, he develops dyspnea, fatigue, and sometimes palpitations. He must rest for several minutes before these symptoms resolve. Which of the following is his New York Heart Association classification?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Class III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This patient's symptoms with less than ordinary activity (walking to the car) but relief at rest align with NYHA Class III , indicating marked limitation of activity but comfort at rest.
  • ➤ NYHA Class III

questions.text: From a pathophysiologic perspective, all of the following are upregulated in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.correct_answer: C. Calcium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Calcium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, compensatory mechanisms like the RAAS and sympathetic nervous system are upregulated, but calcium handling in the sarcoplasmic reticulum is impaired, leading to reduced myocardial function. Thus, calcium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum is not upregulated in HFrEF.
  • ➤ calcium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: You are seeing Mr. Ataley who is a 54-year-old man with dyspnea. After careful physical examination, you suspect cor pulmonale and pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following tests is required to definitively confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension and rule out left heart disease as causal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Right heart catheterization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right heart catheterization is essential for definitively diagnosing pulmonary hypertension and distinguishing it from left heart disease, making it the most appropriate test for confirming the diagnosis.
  • ➤ definitively diagnosing pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman with well controlled diabetes and a history of multiple myeloma who presents with acute headache and undergoes CT scan with IV contrast, which shows no acute intracranial abnormalities. While her admission creatinine was 2.1, on post-admission day 2 it is 2.6 and rises to 3.6 on the next day. She is not dehydrated, she has not received any other nephrotoxic agents, and a diagnosis of contrast-induced nephropathy is made. All of the following are risk factors for contrast-induced nephropathy EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Low-contrast dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CIN is a serious complication of contrast administration. Recognizing the risk factors for CIN allows for appropriate preventive measures, such as adequate hydration and minimizing contrast dose when possible. Paraproteinemia, associated with conditions like multiple myeloma, is a risk factor for CIN.
  • ➤ CIN is a serious complication of contrast administration.
  • ➤ Recognizing the risk factors for CIN allows for appropriate preventive measures, such as adequate hydration and minimizing contrast dose when possible.
  • ➤ Paraproteinemia, associated with conditions like multiple myeloma, is a risk factor for CIN.

questions.text: You are seeing a young man with seizures. As you work to classify the type and etiology of seizure, you know all of the following statements are true, EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Focal seizures originate within networks limited to one brain region.

options.label: B
options.text: Generalized seizures arise within and rapidly engage networks distributed across both cerebral hemispheres.

options.label: C
options.text: Focal seizures are not usually associated with structural abnormalities of the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Focal seizures can evolve into generalized seizures.

questions.correct_answer: C. Focal seizures are not usually associated with structural abnormalities of the brain.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Focal seizures are not usually associated with structural abnormalities of the brain.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Focal seizures are commonly associated with structural abnormalities in the brain. Understanding the different types of seizures and their underlying mechanisms is crucial for proper diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Focal seizures are commonly associated with structural abnormalities in the brain.
  • ➤ Understanding the different types of seizures and their underlying mechanisms is crucial for proper diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness and facial droop. Which of the following is LEAST likely to be a contributing risk factor for his current presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High-density lipoprotein cholesterol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High-density lipoprotein cholesterol is a protective factor against stroke, while diabetes, hypertension, and high LDL cholesterol are significant risk factors. Recognizing and managing these risk factors is crucial in preventing stroke.
  • ➤ High-density lipoprotein cholesterol is a protective factor against stroke, while diabetes, hypertension, and high LDL cholesterol are significant risk factors.
  • ➤ Recognizing and managing these risk factors is crucial in preventing stroke.

questions.text: You are called emergently by a nurse into an emergency department room where Mr. Freeman is a 75-yearold patient who had presented with a headache. He has just returned from head CT where an intracranial hemorrhage was found. On return from CT, he is obtunded and gurgling with arterial oxygenation saturation of 90%. He has minimal response to painful stimuli. Blood pressure is 150/90. What is the next best action?

options.label: D
options.text: Labetalol IV for blood pressure control

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intubation and mechanical ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with impaired consciousness and signs of poor oxygenation, securing the airway with intubation and mechanical ventilation is the immediate priority, especially in the setting of an intracranial hemorrhage where neurologic deterioration can lead to airway compromise and aspiration.Top of Form
  • ➤ intubation and mechanical ventilation

questions.text: While most cases of vascular dementia are sporadic and largely due to environmental/acquired risk factors, some are genetic. The most prevalent is cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy. This disorder is due to a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) NOTCH3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CADASIL is the most common genetic cause of vascular dementia and is due to mutations in the NOTCH3 gene . This condition results in recurrent strokes, cognitive impairment, and other neurological symptoms due to small vessel disease in the brain.
  • ➤ CADASIL
  • ➤ NOTCH3 gene

questions.text: You are seeing a 70 years old male, in the clinic today. He presents with rest tremor, occasional rigidity, generalized bradykinesia, and gait dysfunction with frequent falls. You would expect degeneration of which neuron subtype within the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra

options.label: D
options.text: Serotonergic neurons in the substantia nigra

questions.correct_answer: A. Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parkinson's disease is characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra , leading to the hallmark motor symptoms of the disease, such as tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability.
  • ➤ dopaminergic neurons
  • ➤ substantia nigra

questions.text: 24-year-old with unilateral facial weakness, you diagnose a simple Bell’s palsy without any other neurologic deficits. Laboratory studies including an erythrocyte sedimentation rate, Lyme titer, and angiotensin-converting enzyme level are normal. Chest x-ray is normal. Which of the following is the next most reasonable therapeutic step?

options.label: D
options.text: Prednisone 60 mg daily for 5 days and then tapered over 5 days

questions.correct_answer: D. Prednisone 60 mg daily for 5 days and then tapered over 5 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prednisone 60 mg daily for 5 days and then tapered over 5 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute Bell's palsy , oral corticosteroids (prednisone) initiated early are the most effective treatment to reduce nerve inflammation and improve recovery. Other interventions like IVIg or electrical stimulation are not appropriate for this condition.
  • ➤ acute Bell's palsy
  • ➤ oral corticosteroids (prednisone)

questions.text: A 71-year-old man, for changes in mental status and cognition. His wife reports that he has slowly been worsening over the last year or two. He has frequent visual hallucinations, sleeps heavily during the daytime but not well at night, and has delusions of persecution. He was noted to have some parkinsonian features previously and was started on L-dopa, but quickly developed a hallucinatory delirium requiring cessation of L-dopa. He does not have orthostatic hypotension or syncope. Which of the following diseases best fits his dementia syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dementia with Lewy bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dementia with Lewy bodies is a common cause of dementia, often presenting with visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and parkinsonism. Patients with DLB are highly sensitive to antipsychotic medications and dopamine agonists, which can worsen their symptoms. Recognizing the clinical features of DLB is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management, avoiding medications that can exacerbate their condition.
  • ➤ Dementia with Lewy bodies is a common cause of dementia, often presenting with visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and parkinsonism.
  • ➤ Patients with DLB are highly sensitive to antipsychotic medications and dopamine agonists, which can worsen their symptoms.
  • ➤ Recognizing the clinical features of DLB is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management, avoiding medications that can exacerbate their condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as the "worst headache of her life." She also reports nausea, neck stiffness, and photophobia. A non-contrast CT scan of the head reveals hyperdensity in the basal cisterns and along the sulci. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A sudden, severe headache ("worst headache of life") with CT evidence of hyperdensity in the basal cisterns is most indicative of a subarachnoid hemorrhage , often caused by a ruptured aneurysm.
  • ➤ sudden, severe headache
  • ➤ CT evidence of hyperdensity
  • ➤ subarachnoid hemorrhage

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis. Her symptoms include vision loss in one eye and weakness in her legs. Laboratory testing reveals a positive autoantibody. Which of the following is the most likely target of the autoantibody found in 70% of patients with this clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aquaporin-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neuromyelitis optica (NMO) , the autoantibodies commonly target aquaporin-4 , leading to recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. Detecting these antibodies helps confirm the diagnosis.
  • ➤ neuromyelitis optica (NMO)
  • ➤ aquaporin-4

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is seen for complaints of weakness for the last month. She notes this to be particularly worse in the late afternoon and evening. Initially, she attributed the weakness to stress from her job, but she feels that the weakness is worsening despite taking several days off work. She also is now noticing some occasional double vision, and her husband has noticed that her voice sounds weak. The patient denies pain. On physical examination, you note the appearance of mild ptosis and a nasal, breathy tone to her voice. Which of the following tests would be most sensitive and specific for making a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine receptor antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected myasthenia gravis , testing for acetylcholine receptor antibodies is the most sensitive and specific method to confirm the diagnosis.
  • ➤ myasthenia gravis
  • ➤ acetylcholine receptor antibodies

questions.text: Mr. Rollins is brought to the emergency department on Saturday night. His wife reports that he came home from a late business meeting with altered mental status and ataxia. He was completely normal this afternoon when she visited him at work. On examination, you note that he is moderately somnolent but awakens with voice. He has a bilateral ataxia, which is symmetric. He denies vertigo. Which of the following tests is most likely to discover the etiology of his neurologic abnormalities?

options.label: B
options.text: Brain MRI focusing on fine cuts through the cerebellum

options.label: D
options.text: Lumbar puncture with polymerase chain reaction for varicella zoster

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blood ethanol level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients presenting with acute altered mental status and ataxia, alcohol intoxication is a common and easily reversible cause. A blood ethanol level is a simple and effective diagnostic test in this clinical scenario.
  • ➤ alcohol intoxication
  • ➤ blood ethanol level

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents complaining of weakness. He has a difficult time pinpointing an onset. He believes he first noticed weakness in his right foot and leg about 6 months ago. He reports that he frequently trips over his toes and drags his foot. He also gets frequent cramps when he stretches in bed in the mornings. The weakness is progressing to involve both legs now. On examination, you note tongue fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ at the knees and ankles. Strength is 4– at the extensors and flexors of the right foot and 4+ at the left foot. Hand grip strength is also 4+. Which of the following is the suspected pathologic lesion(s)?

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and degeneration of CST

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of large pyramidal cells in the precentral gyrus

options.label: D
options.text: Lymphocytic infiltrate of spinal roots and nerves

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and degeneration of CST
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Loss of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and degeneration of CST

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ALS involves degeneration of both upper motor neurons (corticospinal tracts) and lower motor neurons (anterior horn cells), leading to a combination of muscle weakness, hyperreflexia, fasciculations, and atrophy, as seen in this patient.
  • ➤ ALS
  • ➤ upper motor neurons
  • ➤ lower motor neurons

questions.text: You have developed a new screening test for disease X. When you compare your test to the gold standard test, you find that you are correctly able to identify 8 of 10 people who have the disease. You next test a population of 50 people without the disease and you identify 3 positive results on your test. Which of the following is true regarding your test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The specificity is 94%.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensitivity: True positive rate Specificity: True negative rate
  • ➤ Sensitivity: True positive rate
  • ➤ Sensitivity:
  • ➤ Specificity: True negative rate
  • ➤ Specificity:
  • ➤ In this case, the new test has a high specificity (94%), meaning it's good at correctly identifying people who don't have the disease. It has a moderate sensitivity (80%), indicating it might miss some people who actually have the disease.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is treated with induction chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. His initial white blood cell count prior to treatment was 156,000/μL. All of the following are expected complications during his treatment EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor lysis syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of chemotherapy in patients with high tumor burden. It's essential to monitor for and manage electrolyte abnormalities and acute kidney injury that may occur due to TLS.
  • ➤ Tumor lysis syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of chemotherapy in patients with high tumor burden.
  • ➤ It's essential to monitor for and manage electrolyte abnormalities and acute kidney injury that may occur due to TLS.
  • ➤ Hypercalcemia is not a typical complication in this setting.

questions.text: As an oncologist, you are considering treatment options for your patients with lung cancer, including small-molecule therapy targeting the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). Which of the following patients is most likely to have an EGFR mutation?

options.label: B
options.text: A 33-year-old woman with a carcinoid tumor

options.label: C
options.text: A 45-year-old woman who has never smoked with an adenocarcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: A 56-year-old man with a 100 pack-year history of tobacco use with small-cell lung carcinoma

questions.correct_answer: C. A 45-year-old woman who has never smoked with an adenocarcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A 45-year-old woman who has never smoked with an adenocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EGFR mutations are important biomarkers in lung cancer, particularly in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). They are more commonly found in never-smokers or light smokers, women, and individuals of Asian ethnicity. Targeted therapies against EGFR mutations have revolutionized the treatment of NSCLC in patients with these mutations.
  • ➤ EGFR mutations are important biomarkers in lung cancer, particularly in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
  • ➤ They are more commonly found in never-smokers or light smokers, women, and individuals of Asian ethnicity.
  • ➤ Targeted therapies against EGFR mutations have revolutionized the treatment of NSCLC in patients with these mutations.

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy comes into the hospital with severe pain in his bilateral hips, arms, and diffuse body aches. He has had similar episodes but has not required hospitalization. He is not on any medications. He plays soccer part of the year but has not been playing recently and has not had any trauma. On initial labs, his comprehensive metabolic panel is normal except for a total bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL. Complete blood count is notable for microcytic anemia. His peripheral smear is shown below. Given the likely diagnosis, which explanation fits with this?

options.label: A
options.text: A somatic mutation that causes deranged messenger RNA splicing of the globin gene.

options.label: C
options.text: Mutation in the β- globin gene that changes the sixth amino acid from glutamic acid to valine.

options.label: D
options.text: One of the four α- globin loci is deleted

questions.correct_answer: C. Mutation in the β- globin gene that changes the sixth amino acid from glutamic acid to valine.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mutation in the β-globin gene that changes the sixth amino acid from glutamic acid to valine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of microcytic anemia, recurrent pain crises, and hemolysis in an adolescent with a likely hemoglobinopathy points to sickle cell disease , which is caused by a mutation in the β-globin gene leading to the production of abnormal hemoglobin S.
  • ➤ microcytic anemia, recurrent pain crises, and hemolysis
  • ➤ sickle cell disease

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is referred to your clinic for evaluation of anemia that was found on a life insurance screening examination. She reports being healthy, takes no medications other than a multivitamin with iron, and only admits some recent fatigue on exertion in the past 6–9 months. She menstruates regularly with 3- to 4-day menses that have not changed in years. She eats a normal omnivorous diet, smokes one pack of cigarettes per day, and does not use illicit drugs. The results of her complete blood count reveal a white blood cell count of 4.0/μL, platelet count of 235,000/μL, and hemoglobin of 8 g/dL with a mean corpuscular volume of 105.Peripheral smear is shown below. She has normal renal and liver function. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pernicious anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The elevated MCV and clinical presentation are most consistent with pernicious anemia , a common cause of B12 deficiency , which leads to megaloblastic anemia despite normal dietary intake due to impaired absorption of B12.
  • ➤ pernicious anemia
  • ➤ B12 deficiency
  • ➤ megaloblastic anemia

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the clinic with fatigue, intermittent fevers, and night sweats for the past 2 weeks. She denies any recent travel or sick contacts. Her physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva but is otherwise normal. Her vital signs are notable only for a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F). The metabolic panel is normal, but her complete blood count reveals a white blood cell count of 900/μL, hemoglobin of 8.0g/dL, and a platelet count of 98,000/ μL. Which of the following is the least likely cause of her current symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Parvovirus infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In this case of pancytopenia with fatigue, fever, and night sweats, parvovirus infection is the least likely cause, as it typically causes isolated anemia rather than pancytopenia. Bone marrow disorders like aplastic anemia , myelodysplastic syndrome , and myelofibrosis are more likely.
  • ➤ parvovirus infection
  • ➤ aplastic anemia
  • ➤ myelodysplastic syndrome
  • ➤ myelofibrosis

questions.text: A 73-year-old-man comes in for follow-up after a recent hospitalization for a car accident in which he was rear-ended. He suffered no injuries and was released from the emergency room after a full examination and monitoring. On labs done in the emergency room, he was noted to have an elevated white blood cell count to 95 × 109/L, predominantly lymphocytes. You do a peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Admission to the hospital for high-dose induction chemotherapy

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with an elevated white blood cell count and predominantly lymphocytes, especially in an elderly patient, chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) should be suspected. Flow cytometry is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis before determining the need for treatment or observation.
  • ➤ chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)
  • ➤ Flow cytometry

questions.text: A 78-year-old female is evaluated by her primary care physician for worsening dyspnea on exertion. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) treated with anti-tumor necrosis factor alpha therapy, which has controlled her joint manifestations. Which of the following additional findings suggest that her dyspnea may be related to RA-associated interstitial lung disease?

options.label: A
options.text: A total lung capacity of 55% predicted with a diffusing capacity for carbon dioxide (DLCO) of 50% predicted

options.label: B
options.text: A total lung capacity of 55% predicted and a DLCO of 90% predicted

options.label: C
options.text: A total lung capacity of 90% predicted with a normal DLCO

options.label: D
options.text: A total lung capacity of 120% predicted with a DLCO of 60% predicted

questions.correct_answer: A. A total lung capacity of 55% predicted with a diffusing capacity for carbon dioxide (DLCO) of 50% predicted
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A total lung capacity of 55% predicted with a diffusing capacity for carbon dioxide (DLCO) of 50% predicted

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with RA-associated interstitial lung disease , pulmonary function tests typically show a restrictive pattern (reduced TLC) with a reduced DLCO , reflecting impaired gas exchange due to lung fibrosis.
  • ➤ RA-associated interstitial lung disease
  • ➤ restrictive pattern
  • ➤ reduced DLCO

questions.text: A 23-year-old male with cystic fibrosis has had an increase in the number of respiratory exacerbations over the last year, despite good compliance with airway clearance techniques and treatment with several rounds of antibiotics for chronic pseudomonas colonization. On examination in your office he has scattered wheezes over his anterior lung fields, as well as bibasilar crackles with rhonchi. CT of the chest reveals extensive upper lobe bronchiectasis with mucus plugging as well as scattered areas of bronchiolitis. In addition to repeat sputum cultures to look for new bacterial and atypical mycobacterial infections, which of the following tests would be indicated at this time?

options.label: C
options.text: CT angiogram to look for pulmonary embolism

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serum IgE levels.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with cystic fibrosis who present with worsening respiratory symptoms and bronchiectasis, especially with mucus plugging , it's important to consider allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) . A serum IgE level is the next best test to evaluate for this condition.
  • ➤ cystic fibrosis
  • ➤ mucus plugging
  • ➤ allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA)
  • ➤ serum IgE level

questions.text: A 24-year old male with known cystic fibrosis (CF) presents to the clinic with worsening cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath over the last 3 weeks. Prior to this episode he has been doing fairly well, and has been compliant with his airway clearance regimen, which includes hypertonic saline nebulizers, inhaled dornase, and twice daily use of a flutter valve to aid with expectoration of sputum. You suspect that he has an acute CF exacerbation. Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhaled tobramycin to cover for likely Pseudomonas

options.label: B
options.text: IV ceftazidime and tobramycin to cover likely Pseudomonas infection

options.label: C
options.text: IV vancomycin and ceftriaxone to cover both methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection as well as possible community-acquired pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: Oral azithromycin, ethambutol, and rifampin to cover likely atypical mycobacterial infection

questions.correct_answer: B. IV ceftazidime and tobramycin to cover likely Pseudomonas infection
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV ceftazidime and tobramycin to cover likely Pseudomonas infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with cystic fibrosis experiencing an acute exacerbation, empiric therapy should cover Pseudomonas aeruginosa , typically with a combination of IV antibiotics like ceftazidime and tobramycin .
  • ➤ cystic fibrosis
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • ➤ IV antibiotics
  • ➤ ceftazidime and tobramycin

questions.text: A 40-year-old presents to the clinic with 6 months of intermittent cough and sputum production, and worsening dyspnea on exertion. He has been treated at an urgent care center twice in the last year for bronchitis. He smokes about 1 pack of cigarettes per day and has done so for the last 20 years. Pulmonary function testing reveals an FEV1/ FVC ratio of 50%, with an FEV1 of 45% predicted. CT of the chest reveals pan-acinar emphysema with slightly worse disease in the lower lobes. What would be the next step in management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Careful environmental history to better understand possible exposure risk to airway irritants and toxins

options.label: C
options.text: Sputum culture to rule out atypical mycobacterial infection

questions.correct_answer: D. Testing for alpha-1 antitrypsin levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Testing for alpha-1 antitrypsin levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a relatively young smoker with pan-acinar emphysema in the lower lobes, testing for alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) is crucial to confirm the diagnosis, as it is a common cause of early-onset emphysema in these patients.
  • ➤ pan-acinar emphysema
  • ➤ alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD)

questions.text: A patient with mild amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is followed by a pulmonologist for respiratory dysfunction associated with his neuromuscular disease. Which of the following symptoms in addition to PaCO2 ≥45 mmHg would necessitate therapy with noninvasive positive pressure ventilation for hypoventilation?

options.label: C
options.text: Dyspnea in activities of daily living

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ALS patients with elevated PaCO2 and symptoms like orthopnea, poor sleep quality , and dyspnea , noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) is indicated to support respiratory function and prevent further respiratory decline.
  • ➤ PaCO2
  • ➤ orthopnea, poor sleep quality
  • ➤ dyspnea

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with worsening cough and exertional dyspnea over the last 2 months. He currently smokes 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day and has done so for 30 years. His pulmonary function tests show a normal FEV1/FVC ratio, a total lung capacity that is 75% of predicted, and a diffusing capacity that is 60% of predicted. High-resolution CT of the chest shows diffuse centrilobular nodules and scattered ground-glass opacities. Which of the following treatments would be most likely effective for his interstitial lung disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Smoking cessation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with smoking-related interstitial lung disease like RB-ILD , smoking cessation is the primary and most effective treatment. Continuing to smoke can exacerbate lung damage, whereas quitting can halt disease progression and improve symptoms.
  • ➤ smoking-related interstitial lung disease
  • ➤ RB-ILD
  • ➤ smoking cessation

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a history of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) presents with fatigue, nausea, and low blood pressure. He has been on anti-tuberculosis therapy (ATT) for 4 months. On examination, he is hypotensive with hyperpigmented skin. Lab tests show hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Adrenal hemorrhage due to miliary tuberculosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Adrenal hemorrhage due to miliary tuberculosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adrenal hemorrhage due to miliary tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis can lead to adrenal hemorrhage and subsequent adrenal insufficiency, which presents with hypotension , electrolyte imbalances (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia), and fatigue . Recognizing these signs is crucial in patients on anti-tuberculosis therapy .
  • ➤ Miliary tuberculosis
  • ➤ adrenal hemorrhage
  • ➤ hypotension
  • ➤ electrolyte imbalances
  • ➤ fatigue
  • ➤ anti-tuberculosis therapy

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was admitted to the intensive care unit with a large intracranial bleed following a motorcycle accident. On initial CT scan, there was midline shift and evidence of uncal herniation. At the scene of the accident, the patient was initially minimally responsive but has been totally unresponsive to all stimuli since admission. The patient was intubated by emergency medical services en route to the hospital. He has now been admitted for 24 hours. You believe the patient is brain dead. Which of the following contributes to the diagnosis of brain death?

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are criteria for assessment of brain death

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above are criteria for assessment of brain death
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above are criteria for assessment of brain death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of brain death requires the absence of all brainstem reflexes (including pupillary light reflex and oculovestibular reflex), and a positive apnea test , confirming the irreversible loss of brain function.
  • ➤ brain death
  • ➤ apnea test

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with relapsed acute myelogenous leukemia has undergone a myeloablative allogeneic stem cell transplantation. She has been profoundly neutropenic for 21 days and has had a persistent fever for the past 7 days. Today, she has appeared septic with hypotension, tachycardia, and a new oxygen requirement. A nurse calls you to evaluate a new rash. On examination, the patient looks ill. She is tachypneic and is rigoring. Skin examination reveals a few scattered areas of hemorrhagic vesicles, the largest measuring 3 cm in diameter, on the hands and legs. Image is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ecthyma gangrenosum is a cutaneous manifestation of invasive infection, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is often seen in immunocompromised patients with prolonged neutropenia. Recognizing the characteristic skin lesions and the associated clinical context is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ Ecthyma gangrenosum is a cutaneous manifestation of invasive infection, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • ➤ It is often seen in immunocompromised patients with prolonged neutropenia.
  • ➤ Recognizing the characteristic skin lesions and the associated clinical context is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and presents to your office for routine follow-up. He has no complaints currently and feels well. His most recent FEV1 was 55% predicted, and he is not on oxygen. He received one dose of pneumococcal vaccine 7 years previously. He is asking whether he should receive another dose of pneumococcal vaccine. According to the guidelines of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, what is your recommendation?

options.label: A
options.text: He does not require further vaccination unless his FEV1 drops below 50% predicted.

options.label: B
options.text: He does not require further vaccination until he reaches age 65.

options.label: D
options.text: He should be revaccinated 10 years after his initial vaccine.

questions.correct_answer: C. He should be revaccinated today.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) He should be revaccinated today.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adults with chronic lung disease, including COPD, should receive two pneumococcal vaccines: PCV13 and PPSV23. Revaccination with PPSV23 is recommended 5 years after the first PPSV23 dose.
  • ➤ Adults with chronic lung disease, including COPD, should receive two pneumococcal vaccines: PCV13 and PPSV23.
  • ➤ Revaccination with PPSV23 is recommended 5 years after the first PPSV23 dose.

questions.text: You admit a patient with severe community-acquired pneumonia who requires intubation and mechanical ventilation. She has decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion halfway up her right lung. Chest x-ray and ultrasound confirm the presence of a large pleural effusion. You perform a diagnostic thoracentesis, but fluid remains. All of the following are indications for complete drainage of the pleural fluid EXCEPT:

options.label: D
options.text: Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase concentration >1000 units/L

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pleural fluid protein > 5 g/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with severe pneumonia and a large pleural effusion, certain pleural fluid findings (low pH, low glucose, high LDH) are indicative of empyema and necessitate complete drainage. A high pleural fluid protein level alone is not an absolute indication for complete drainage. Further investigation and clinical correlation are necessary to determine the appropriate management.
  • ➤ In a patient with severe pneumonia and a large pleural effusion, certain pleural fluid findings (low pH, low glucose, high LDH) are indicative of empyema and necessitate complete drainage.
  • ➤ A high pleural fluid protein level alone is not an absolute indication for complete drainage. Further investigation and clinical correlation are necessary to determine the appropriate management.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a past medical history of hypertension presents to her primary care doctor prior to a 2-week long mission trip her church is taking to Guatemala. You provide her with extensive pretravel counseling and treatment. You could provide her with all of the following guidance and prophylaxis regarding the prevention of traveler’s diarrhea EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Avoid raw vegetables, salads, and unpeeled fruit.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Take ciprofloxacin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Traveler's diarrhea prevention primarily focuses on dietary and hygiene practices, such as avoiding contaminated food and water. Bismuth subsalicylate and probiotics can be considered for prophylaxis in some cases. Antibiotics like ciprofloxacin are reserved for the treatment of traveler's diarrhea if it occurs, not for routine prophylaxis.
  • ➤ Traveler's diarrhea prevention primarily focuses on dietary and hygiene practices, such as avoiding contaminated food and water.
  • ➤ Bismuth subsalicylate and probiotics can be considered for prophylaxis in some cases.
  • ➤ Antibiotics like ciprofloxacin are reserved for the treatment of traveler's diarrhea if it occurs, not for routine prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is the most sensitive to make the appropriate diagnosis in a woman seen at a sexually transmitted disease clinic with profuse, yellow, and purulent, homogenous vaginal discharge with vulvar irritation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nucleic acid amplification test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NAAT is the preferred diagnostic test for most STIs due to its high sensitivity and specificity.
  • ➤ NAAT is the preferred diagnostic test for most STIs due to its high sensitivity and specificity.
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with purulent vaginal discharge and vulvar irritation, NAAT should be performed to rule out Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman has recurrent urinary tract infections. She is placed on suppressive antibiotic therapy by her primary physician. One year later, she is complaining of progressive dyspnea, and a chest radiograph shows development of pulmonary fibrosis. Which antibiotic could explain development of this complication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nitrofurantoin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nitrofurantoin, although effective for urinary tract infections, carries a risk of pulmonary toxicity, including fibrosis, especially with long-term use. Monitor patients on long-term nitrofurantoin for respiratory symptoms and consider alternative antibiotics if pulmonary complications develop.
  • ➤ Nitrofurantoin, although effective for urinary tract infections, carries a risk of pulmonary toxicity, including fibrosis, especially with long-term use.
  • ➤ Monitor patients on long-term nitrofurantoin for respiratory symptoms and consider alternative antibiotics if pulmonary complications develop.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with a history of developmental delay who lives in a group home is brought to the hospital for weakness starting in the head and descending to her legs. She has symmetric cranial nerve palsies, inability to move, and decreased breathing. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. On examination, she is taking only shallow respirations, and you note flaccid muscle tone throughout. There was no preceding fever, cough, coryza, rash, or new medications. She was recently given amoxicillin-clavulanate for sinusitis. She had been eating many foods created with prepared meats. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Botulinum toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulism is a medical emergency that requires prompt recognition and treatment with antitoxin. The classic presentation is descending flaccid paralysis with cranial nerve involvement and potential respiratory failure. A history of consuming improperly canned or preserved food is a crucial clue to the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Botulism is a medical emergency that requires prompt recognition and treatment with antitoxin.
  • ➤ The classic presentation is descending flaccid paralysis with cranial nerve involvement and potential respiratory failure.
  • ➤ A history of consuming improperly canned or preserved food is a crucial clue to the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with prerenal azotemia secondary to dehydration. His creatinine was initially 3.6 mg/dL on admission, but it has improved today to 2.1 mg/dL. He complains of mild lower back pain, and you prescribe naproxen to be taken intermittently. By what mechanism might this drug further impair his renal function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NSAIDs , such as naproxen, can impair renal function by causing afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction , reducing renal perfusion, particularly in patients with conditions like prerenal azotemia .
  • ➤ NSAIDs
  • ➤ afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction
  • ➤ prerenal azotemia

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease is maintained on daily peritoneal dialysis. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Her medications include losartan and warfarin. Two days ago she developed a lesion on her abdominal wall, which is shown below. All of the following statements regarding her condition are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Oral calcium supplement may be a risk factor.

options.label: D
options.text: Severe hyperparathyroidism may not be present.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas co-infection is typical

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calciphylaxis is a serious condition involving vascular calcification and skin necrosis in patients with end-stage renal disease . Secondary infections are common, but Pseudomonas is not typically involved. Risk factors include hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and imbalances in calcium-phosphate metabolism.
  • ➤ Calciphylaxis
  • ➤ end-stage renal disease
  • ➤ Pseudomonas

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese female with a 5-year history of mild hypertension controlled by a thiazide diuretic is evaluated for proteinuria noted on a urine dipstick during a routine visit. Physical examination shows mild pedal edema and laboratory tests reveal serum creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL and proteinuria of 5.9 g/dL. A renal biopsy was taken and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Focal segmental sclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, particularly in obese individuals. It is characterized by nephrotic-range proteinuria and segmental scarring of the glomeruli on renal biopsy.
  • ➤ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
  • ➤ nephrotic-range proteinuria
  • ➤ segmental scarring of the glomeruli

questions.text: A patient with a history of Sjögren syndrome has the following laboratory findings: plasma sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 112 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L, and potassium 3.0 mEq/L. Urine studies show a pH of 6.0, sodium of 15 mEq/L, potassium of 10 mEq/L, and chloride of 12 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type I RTA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type I (distal) RTA is associated with conditions like Sjögren syndrome and presents with a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis , hypokalemia , and an inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5) despite systemic acidosis. This impaired excretion of H+ leads to chronic acidosis and electrolyte abnormalities.
  • ➤ Type I (distal) RTA
  • ➤ Sjögren syndrome
  • ➤ non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ hypokalemia
  • ➤ inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is in the 30th week of her second pregnancy has been followed closely because of mild hypertension. Her first pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. She now complains of worsening fatigue over the last day. Her blood pressure is 140/90, and she has a heart rate of 84 beats/min and room air oxygen saturation of 95%. Fetal monitoring shows no distress. Laboratory studies are notable for a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL (10 g/ dL 1 week ago) and platelet count of 80,000/dL (180,000/ dL 1 week ago). A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. All of the following statements are true about her condition EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Glucocorticoids are effective in reducing morbidity and mortality.

options.label: B
options.text: Her liver function enzymes are likely elevated.

questions.correct_answer: A. Glucocorticoids are effective in reducing morbidity and mortality.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucocorticoids are effective in reducing morbidity and mortality

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HELLP syndrome is a serious complication of pregnancy involving hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets . Treatment involves urgent delivery, as continuing the pregnancy increases maternal and fetal risks. Glucocorticoids are not effective for reducing morbidity and mortality in HELLP syndrome, making this option incorrect
  • ➤ HELLP syndrome
  • ➤ hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets
  • ➤ not effective

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of recurrent calcium oxalate kidney stones presents to your clinic for follow-up. He is interested in learning about interventions to prevent future stone formation. He has been advised on dietary modifications in the past but is unsure which strategies are most effective. Which of the following interventions has been shown to decrease the recurrence of calcium oxalate renal stones?

options.label: A
options.text: A diet with abundant spinach and rhubarb

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiazide diuretics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics are effective in preventing the recurrence of calcium oxalate kidney stones by reducing urinary calcium excretion. Dietary calcium should not be excessively restricted, and oxalate-rich foods like spinach and rhubarb should be limited.
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics
  • ➤ calcium oxalate kidney stones

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive man presents with sudden-onset flank pain, hematuria, and dysuria. He has been on antiretroviral therapy for several years. His drugs include Abacavir, Lamivudine, Indinavir and Rosuvastatin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Indinavir-induced nephrolithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indinavir , a protease inhibitor, can cause radiolucent nephrolithiasis due to drug crystallization in the urinary tract. Patients on indinavir who develop flank pain and hematuria should be evaluated for this type of kidney stone.
  • ➤ Indinavir
  • ➤ radiolucent nephrolithiasis
  • ➤ indinavir

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a known history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) presents with sudden-onset, severe right-sided flank pain. He denies fever, dysuria, or hematuria. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg, and his creatinine is stable at 1.5 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows trace blood but no signs of infection. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cyst rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with ADPKD can experience sudden flank pain due to cyst rupture , which may be accompanied by mild hematuria. This diagnosis should be considered when pain occurs without signs of infection or significant changes in renal function.
  • ➤ ADPKD
  • ➤ cyst rupture

questions.text: A 57-year-old female wishes to undergo a screening colonoscopy for colon cancer. She has no family history of colon cancer and currently has no symptoms referable to the gastrointestinal tract. Which of the following statements is true about colonoscopy as a screening test for colon cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Barium enema is as sensitive as colonoscopy for detecting colitis.

options.label: B
options.text: Colonoscopy remains the gold standard for imaging the colonic mucosa.

options.label: C
options.text: CT colonography has replaced traditional colonoscopy for many younger patients because of its ability to detect serrated polyps with greater sensitivity.

options.label: D
options.text: Flexible sigmoidoscopy would be as effective as colonoscopy for detecting colon cancer in this patient

questions.correct_answer: B. Colonoscopy remains the gold standard for imaging the colonic mucosa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Colonoscopy remains the gold standard for imaging the colonic mucosa.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Colonoscopy is the gold standard for screening and diagnosing colorectal cancer due to its high sensitivity and the ability to remove polyps during the procedure. Other imaging modalities like CT colonography and flexible sigmoidoscopy have their roles but are not as comprehensive as colonoscopy for detecting all colorectal neoplasia.
  • ➤ Colonoscopy is the gold standard for screening and diagnosing colorectal cancer due to its high sensitivity and the ability to remove polyps during the procedure.
  • ➤ Other imaging modalities like CT colonography and flexible sigmoidoscopy have their roles but are not as comprehensive as colonoscopy for detecting all colorectal neoplasia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for chest pain that developed at a restaurant after swallowing a piece of steak. He reports intermittent episodes of meat getting stuck in his lower chest over the past 3 years, but none as severe as this event. He denies food regurgitation outside of these episodes or heartburn symptoms. He is able to swallow liquids without difficulty and has not had any weight loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Schatzki ring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schatzki ring is a common cause of intermittent dysphagia to solids, often triggered by poorly chewed meat. Recognizing the typical presentation can lead to timely diagnosis and appropriate management, such as endoscopic dilation.
  • ➤ Schatzki ring is a common cause of intermittent dysphagia to solids, often triggered by poorly chewed meat.
  • ➤ Recognizing the typical presentation can lead to timely diagnosis and appropriate management, such as endoscopic dilation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia over a 2-month period. He has noted that food has been getting stuck more frequently in the last 2 weeks. He has a history of intermittent gastroesophageal reflux disease for which he takes over-the-counter antacids every few weeks. He has a history of eczema as a child but is not currently requiring treatment. He undergoes an esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which is shown below along with the biopsy. Which of the following is the most appropriate first step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Trial of a proton pump inhibitor

questions.correct_answer: D. Trial of a proton pump inhibitor
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trial of a proton pump inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of EoE should be individualized, and a trial of PPI is often a reasonable first step in patients with a history of GERD. If symptoms persist, further evaluation and EoE-specific therapies can be considered.
  • ➤ The management of EoE should be individualized, and a trial of PPI is often a reasonable first step in patients with a history of GERD.
  • ➤ If symptoms persist, further evaluation and EoE-specific therapies can be considered.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with peptic ulcer disease experiences transient improvement with Helicobacter pylori eradication. However, 3 months later, symptoms recur despite acid-suppressing therapy. He does not take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Stool analysis for H. pylori antigen is negative. Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy reveals prominent gastric folds together with the persistent ulceration in the duodenal bulb previously detected and the beginning of a new ulceration 4 cm proximal to the initial ulcer. Fasting gastrin levels are elevated, and basal acid secretion is 15 mEq/h. What is the best test to perform to make the diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Blood sampling for gastrin levels following a meal.

options.label: C
options.text: Blood sampling for gastrin levels following secretin administration.

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood sampling for gastrin levels following secretin administration.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blood sampling for gastrin levels following secretin administration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zollinger-Ellison syndrome should be suspected in patients with recurrent or refractory peptic ulcers, especially with elevated gastrin levels. The secretin stimulation test is the gold standard for diagnosing ZES. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications and improve outcomes.
  • ➤ Zollinger-Ellison syndrome should be suspected in patients with recurrent or refractory peptic ulcers, especially with elevated gastrin levels.
  • ➤ The secretin stimulation test is the gold standard for diagnosing ZES.
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is evaluated by a gastroenterologist for diarrhea that has been present for approximately 1 month. He reports stools that float and are difficult to flush down the toilet; these can occur at any time of day or night but seem worsened by fatty meals. In addition, he reports pain in many joints lasting days to weeks and not relieved by ibuprofen. His wife notes that the patient has had difficulty with memory for the last few months. He has lost 16kg and reports intermittent low-grade fevers. He takes no medications and is otherwise healthy. Endoscopy is recommended. Which of the following is the most likely finding on small bowel biopsy?

options.label: C
options.text: Mononuclear cell infiltrate in the lamina propria

options.label: D
options.text: Periodic acid–Schiff-positive macrophages containing small bacilli

questions.correct_answer: D. Periodic acid–Schiff-positive macrophages containing small bacilli
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) Periodic acid–Schiff-positive macrophages containing small bacilli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Whipple's disease is a rare systemic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It presents with a combination of malabsorption, arthralgias, and neurological symptoms. The diagnosis is confirmed by identifying PAS-positive macrophages containing bacilli in a small bowel biopsy. Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics are essential for a good outcome.
  • ➤ Whipple's disease is a rare systemic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei.
  • ➤ It presents with a combination of malabsorption, arthralgias, and neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ The diagnosis is confirmed by identifying PAS-positive macrophages containing bacilli in a small bowel biopsy.
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics are essential for a good outcome.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male from Mexico was found to be purified protein derivative–positive on routine health screening prior to beginning a new job in a hospital. He was started on isoniazid for treatment of latent tuberculosis. Three months into his treatment course he develops numbness and tingling in his bilateral feet. On laboratory assessment his liver function tests are normal. He reports taking his isoniazid faithfully but does not remember being told to take any additional medications along with the isoniazid. Which of the following is the likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin B6 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isoniazid can cause vitamin B6 deficiency, leading to peripheral neuropathy. It is crucial to supplement patients on isoniazid with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to prevent this complication. Recognizing the symptoms of vitamin B6 deficiency and promptly initiating supplementation can help prevent long-term neurological damage
  • ➤ Isoniazid can cause vitamin B6 deficiency, leading to peripheral neuropathy.
  • ➤ It is crucial to supplement patients on isoniazid with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to prevent this complication.
  • ➤ Recognizing the symptoms of vitamin B6 deficiency and promptly initiating supplementation can help prevent long-term neurological damage

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with episodic abdominal pain and stress-induced edema of the lips, tongue, and occasionally the larynx. He has no history of allergies or new medications. What is the most likely deficiency in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) C1 esterase inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hereditary angioedema is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 esterase inhibitor , leading to episodes of non-allergic, non-IgE mediated angioedema that can affect the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and airways.
  • ➤ Hereditary angioedema
  • ➤ C1 esterase inhibitor
  • ➤ non-allergic, non-IgE mediated angioedema

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with hypoxemia. His partner tells the intensive care team that he has been coughing up blood for the last 2 days in increasing amounts. On laboratory studies his creatinine is markedly elevated. He is ultimately diagnosed with Goodpasture syndrome. What is the immune mechanism leading to organ damage in Goodpasture syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B)  Complement-activating autoantibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease in which complement-activating autoantibodies target the basement membranes of the kidneys and lungs, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage .
  • ➤ Goodpasture syndrome
  • ➤ complement-activating autoantibodies
  • ➤ basement membranes
  • ➤ glomerulonephritis
  • ➤ pulmonary hemorrhage

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with long-standing diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus is evaluated by her rheumatologist as routine follow-up. A new cardiac murmur is heard, and an echocardiogram is ordered. She is feeling well and has no fevers, weight loss, or pre-existing cardiac disease. A vegetation on the mitral valve is demonstrated. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood cultures are unlikely to be positive.

options.label: B
options.text: Glucocorticoid therapy has been proven to lead to improvement in this condition.

options.label: D
options.text: The lesion has a low risk of embolization.

questions.correct_answer: A. Blood cultures are unlikely to be positive.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blood cultures are unlikely to be positive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Libman-Sacks endocarditis is associated with SLE and characterized by sterile vegetations on cardiac valves, most commonly the mitral valve. Blood cultures are typically negative , and there is a risk of embolization from these vegetations.
  • ➤ Libman-Sacks endocarditis
  • ➤ SLE
  • ➤ sterile vegetations
  • ➤ negative
  • ➤ embolization

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of Sjögren’s syndrome presents for prenatal care. She is 22 weeks pregnant, and routine fetal heart monitoring reveals bradycardia. Testing confirms the presence of anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies. Which of the following conditions is most likely to affect the newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neonatal congenital heart block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In mothers with autoimmune conditions like Sjögren’s syndrome or SLE who test positive for anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies , there is an increased risk of the fetus developing congenital heart block (CHB) , which can lead to fetal bradycardia and may require close fetal monitoring.
  • ➤ Sjögren’s syndrome
  • ➤ SLE
  • ➤ anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies
  • ➤ congenital heart block (CHB)
  • ➤ fetal bradycardia

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness over the past few months. She also reports a red, scaly rash over her knuckles and a purple discoloration of her eyelids. Physical exam reveals symmetrical muscle weakness in her shoulders and hips. Laboratory tests show elevated creatine kinase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)  Dermatomyositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dermatomyositis is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin findings such as Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash . Elevated creatine kinase confirms muscle involvement, distinguishing it from other autoimmune diseases.
  • ➤ Dermatomyositis
  • ➤ proximal muscle weakness
  • ➤ Gottron's papules
  • ➤ heliotrope rash
  • ➤ creatine kinase

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated for weakness. She has had several weeks of difficulty brushing her teeth and combing her hair. She has also noted a rash on her face. Examination is notable for a heliotrope rash and proximal muscle weakness. Serum CPK is elevated, and she is diagnosed with dermatomyositis. After evaluation, she is found to have anti-Jo-1 antibodies. She is also likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C)  Interstitial lung disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with dermatomyositis and anti-Jo-1 antibodies are at an increased risk for interstitial lung disease , which requires careful monitoring and management alongside their muscle disease.
  • ➤ dermatomyositis
  • ➤ anti-Jo-1 antibodies
  • ➤ interstitial lung disease

questions.text: A 34-year-old man who presented to you with unexplained pancreatitis 2 weeks ago. Imaging of his pancreas showed diffuse pancreatic enlargement. He denies any alcohol intake and did not have any gallstones on imaging. Interestingly, on examination, he also has marked lacrimal gland and submandibular gland enlargement. Biopsy of his submandibular gland is shown below. The cells pictured in the figure stain strongly positive for IgG4, CD19, and CD138. Which of the following is the appropriate therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prednisone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgG4-related disease is a multisystem autoimmune disorder characterized by IgG4-positive plasma cell infiltration , often affecting the pancreas, salivary glands, and other organs. The treatment of choice is corticosteroids , such as prednisone , which can lead to remission in most cases.
  • ➤ IgG4-related disease
  • ➤ IgG4-positive plasma cell infiltration
  • ➤ corticosteroids
  • ➤ prednisone

questions.text: Production of which of the following hormones would be most impaired by lesions that affect the pituitary stalk or hypothalamus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oxytocin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesions affecting the pituitary stalk primarily impair the release of posterior pituitary hormones (oxytocin and ADH) due to disruption of their transport and storage. Anterior pituitary hormones can still be produced to some extent, and prolactin levels would actually increase due to the loss of dopamine inhibition.
  • ➤ Lesions affecting the pituitary stalk primarily impair the release of posterior pituitary hormones (oxytocin and ADH) due to disruption of their transport and storage.
  • ➤ Anterior pituitary hormones can still be produced to some extent, and prolactin levels would actually increase due to the loss of dopamine inhibition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with new-onset headaches. Brain MRI reveals a pituitary lesion. Which of the following laboratory findings is MOST likely associated with a non-functioning pituitary adenoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Elevated prolactin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-functioning pituitary adenomas can cause hormonal imbalances through mass effect and compression of the pituitary stalk.
  • ➤ Elevated prolactin levels due to the "stalk effect" are a common and characteristic finding in non-functioning pituitary adenomas.
  • ➤ Recognizing the potential for hormonal dysfunction in patients with pituitary lesions is crucial, prompting appropriate laboratory investigations.

questions.text: A 38-year-old mother of three presents to her primary care office with complaints of fatigue. She feels that her energy level has been low for the past 3 months. She was previously healthy and taking no medications. She does report that she has gained about 6 Kg weight and has severe constipation, for which she has been taking a number of laxatives. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is elevated at 25 mU/L. Free T4 is low. She is wondering why she has hypothyroidism. Which of the following tests is most likely to diagnose the etiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antithyroid peroxidase antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antithyroid peroxidase antibody is the most useful test to diagnose Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism.
  • ➤ Antithyroid peroxidase antibody is the most useful test to diagnose Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism.
  • ➤ Other tests may be helpful in certain situations, but TPO antibody is the initial test of choice in most cases.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic reporting ankle swelling. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated at 162/86, and he has bilateral ankle edema. There are no other abnormalities on physical examination. Laboratory studies show a potassium of 2.9 and normal creatinine. Which of the following studies is recommended next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasma renin and aldosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and normal renal function, primary hyperaldosteronism should be strongly suspected. The plasma renin and aldosterone test is the initial diagnostic test of choice to confirm the diagnosis. If the test is positive, further imaging (e.g., CT of adrenals) may be needed to identify the underlying cause
  • ➤ In a patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and normal renal function, primary hyperaldosteronism should be strongly suspected.
  • ➤ The plasma renin and aldosterone test is the initial diagnostic test of choice to confirm the diagnosis.
  • ➤ If the test is positive, further imaging (e.g., CT of adrenals) may be needed to identify the underlying cause

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue, hair loss, and constipation. She has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus that is well controlled on insulin and celiac disease, which she manages with a gluten-free diet. On physical examination she has dry skin but no other obvious abnormalities. On laboratory studies, her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 85 mU/L and thyroid peroxidase antibodies are elevated. What is her underlying syndrome?

options.label: C
options.text: Immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked disease

options.label: D
options.text: Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, M-protein, and skin changes

questions.explanation:
Ans.  B)  APS-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of autoimmune thyroid disease and type 1 diabetes in a young woman is highly suggestive of APS-2. Patients with APS-2 should be monitored for other autoimmune conditions, including Addison's disease, as early detection and treatment can improve outcomes.
  • ➤ The combination of autoimmune thyroid disease and type 1 diabetes in a young woman is highly suggestive of APS-2.
  • ➤ Patients with APS-2 should be monitored for other autoimmune conditions, including Addison's disease, as early detection and treatment can improve outcomes.

questions.text: An infant is noted to have ambiguous genitalia at birth. The baby has fused labia with clitoral enlargement. The karyotype is 46 XX. The baby has increased levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone on laboratory studies. Which of the following biochemical abnormalities may be seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyponatremia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a group of inherited disorders affecting adrenal hormone production. 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form and can present with ambiguous genitalia in females and salt-wasting crisis in both sexes. Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia are the characteristic biochemical abnormalities in 21-hydroxylase deficiency
  • ➤ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a group of inherited disorders affecting adrenal hormone production.
  • ➤ 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form and can present with ambiguous genitalia in females and salt-wasting crisis in both sexes.
  • ➤ Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia are the characteristic biochemical abnormalities in 21-hydroxylase deficiency

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the clinic with his spouse complaining of erectile dysfunction. He has a 10-year history of moderately controlled diabetes mellitus and uses insulin. Over the last year, despite intact libido, he has been unable to attain or sustain an erection when attempting sexual intercourse with his wife. He reports that over this time he no longer awakes with an erection as he did previously. Serum chemistries are normal, hemoglobin A1c is 5.8%, and serum testosterone is normal for his age. Which class of drug is most likely to improve his ability to achieve and maintain erection?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with ED and risk factors for vascular disease (age, diabetes), PDE5 inhibitors are the most appropriate first-line treatment, especially when testosterone levels are normal. Other treatment options may be considered if PDE5 inhibitors are ineffective or contraindicated.
  • ➤ In a patient with ED and risk factors for vascular disease (age, diabetes), PDE5 inhibitors are the most appropriate first-line treatment, especially when testosterone levels are normal.
  • ➤ Other treatment options may be considered if PDE5 inhibitors are ineffective or contraindicated.
